intro: Digitalis flava, commonly known as the yellow foxglove, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the genus Digitalis, which includes several species known for their striking, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring lance-shaped leaves and yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late spring. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. The flowers are pollinated primarily by bumblebees, which are attracted to their nectar-rich structure.
